headline.main: What if My Employer Decides Not to Offer Insurance?

docs.abstract: Employers will be subject to a fine of $2,000 per employee if they don't offer health insurance. Some may choose the penalty, according to one expert, but most are likely to continue to offer coverage.
docs.snippet: Employers will be subject to a fine of $2,000 per employee if they don't offer health insurance. Some may choose the penalty, according to one expert, but most are likely to continue to offer coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'd like to thank everyone who took the time to comment on my posts about cash flow. Here are some of those comments and a few further thoughts:One suggestion: use a credit union instead of a bank. Banks like to hold funds to make money off of the float.

headline.main: Responding to My Week in Cash Flow

docs.abstract: I'm not spinning my story to try to scare people. I'm trying to present a viewpoint that I haven't seen very often in the business press.
docs.snippet: I'm not spinning my story to try to scare people. I'm trying to present a viewpoint that I haven't seen very often in the business press.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's fair to say that time hasn't softened Representative John A. Boehner's take on the new health care law.

headline.main: Boehner: Efforts to Highlight Law's Implementation Are 'Propaganda'

docs.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY The Patient Money column on May 1, about health care providers' billing patients for the balance of fees not covered by insurance, described Medicare rules on the practice incorrectly. While federal law generally prohibits balance billing by providers paid under Medicare, it does not forbid it in all instances. (A doctor who is not formally part of the federal Medicare system, but who treats a Medicare patient and submits a claim to the federal government, is allowed to bill that patient for a small portion of the unpaid balance.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Suzanne Turner, a member of the South Orange Maplewood Presidents Council, an organization comprised of the district's Parent Teacher Association (PTA), Parent Teacher Organization (PTO) and Home and School Association (HSA) presidents, sent a letter of protest this week to Gov. Christopher J. Christie, members of his administration and state legislators.

headline.main: Parents, Teachers to Christie: Restore Funds

docs.abstract: The South Orange Maplewood Presidents Council sent a letter to Governor Christie and members of the New Jersey State Legislature calling for solutions to the current school budget crises.
docs.snippet: The South Orange Maplewood Presidents Council sent a letter to Governor Christie and members of the New Jersey State Legislature calling for solutions to the current school budget crises.

docs.lead_paragraph: As long as I'm talking about alternative health care bills, it's worth lingering over some of the latest news about the bill we actually got. First, the C.B.O. has released a new estimate of how much additional discretionary spending - on implementation costs, further subsidies for new and existing programs, etc. - health care reform is likely to generate over the first 10 years. The total comes to $115 billion above and beyond the official price tag, a sum that would almost wipe out the bill's projected deficit savings in the first decade.
docs.abstract: More evidence that they may be larger than predicted.
docs.snippet: More evidence that they may be larger than predicted.
